description: Represents the number one. It's a fundamental radical and component in many other kanji, used for counting, dates (like the first day), and indicating 'one of something'.
Represents the number two. Commonly used in counting, for the month of February (二月), and in various compound words.
Represents the number three. Used for counting, dates (the third day), the month of March (三月), and in words like 'triangle' (三角形).
kunyomi: み, み.つ, みっ.つ

description: Represents the number four. It has two common readings, 'yon' and 'shi'. The reading 'shi' is sometimes avoided as it has the same sound as the word for death (死).
kunyomi: よ, よ.つ, よっ.つ, よん

description: Represents the number five. Used in counting, time (five o'clock), the month of May (五月), and money.
Represents the number six. It's used in counting, for dates like the sixth day of the month (六日, muika), and for the month of June (六月).
kunyomi: む, む.つ, むっ.つ, むい

description: Represents the number seven. It has two common readings, 'nana' and 'shichi'. Used for the month of July (七月) and for the Tanabata festival (七夕).
kunyomi: なな, なな.つ, なの

description: Represents the number eight. Its shape is considered lucky because it widens at the bottom, suggesting growing prosperity. Used for the month of August (八月).
kunyomi: や, や.つ, やっ.つ, よう

description: Represents the number nine. The reading 'ku' is sometimes avoided as it sounds like the word for suffering (苦), so 'kyuu' is often used instead. Used for the month of September (九月).
Represents the number ten. This kanji is a fundamental building block for larger numbers, such as eleven (十一) and one hundred (百). Used for the month of October (十月).
Represents the number one hundred. The pronunciation can change depending on the number preceding it (e.g., 三百 is 'sanbyaku', 六百 is 'roppyaku').
Represents the number one thousand. Like 'hundred', its pronunciation can also change with certain numbers (e.g., 三千 is 'sanzen').
Represents ten thousand. This is a primary unit for counting large numbers in Japanese. For example, 100,000 is written as 十万 (ten ten-thousands).
This kanji means 'yen', the currency of Japan. It can also mean 'circle' or 'round', and is read as 'maru' in that context.
meaning_mm: ယန်း၊ စက်ဝိုင်း

description: A very common kanji for 'person'. The reading changes based on context: 'hito' when used alone, 'jin' for nationalities (e.g., 日本人 - nihonjin), and 'nin' for counting people (e.g., 三人 - sannin).
A core kanji meaning 'sun', 'day', or 'Japan'. It's used in days of the week (日曜日 - Sunday), dates (e.g., 26日 - 26th day), and in the name of Japan (日本 - Nihon).
meaning_mm: နေ့၊ နေ၊ ဂျပန်

description: This kanji means 'moon' or 'month'. It is used for Monday (月曜日 - getsuyoubi) and to count months (e.g., 九月 - kugatsu, September).
Represents 'fire'. It is the first kanji in the word for Tuesday (火曜日 - kayoubi).
Represents 'water'. It is used in the word for Wednesday (水曜日 - suiyoubi).
Represents 'tree' or 'wood'. It is used in the word for Thursday (木曜日 - mokuyoubi).
meaning_mm: သစ်ပင်၊ သစ်သား

description: Represents 'gold', 'metal', and by extension, 'money'. It is used in the word for Friday (金曜日 - kinyoubi) and money (お金 - okane).
Represents 'earth', 'soil', or 'ground'. It is used in the word for Saturday (土曜日 - doyoubi).
This kanji is used as a suffix for the days of the week, as in 月曜日 (getsuyoubi - Monday). It does not typically appear on its own.
meaning_mm: ရက်သတ္တပတ်၏နေ့

description: Means 'up', 'above', 'on', or 'top'. It is the opposite of 下 (shita - down). Can also be part of verbs like 上がる (agaru - to go up).
kunyomi: うえ, あ.がる, のぼ.る
meaning_mm: အပေါ်၊ အထက်

description: Means 'down', 'below', 'under', or 'bottom'. It is the opposite of 上 (ue - up). Can also be part of verbs like 下がる (sagaru - to go down).
kunyomi: した, さ.がる, くだ.る
meaning_mm: အောက်၊ အောက်တွင်

description: Means 'middle', 'center', or 'inside'. Used in words like China (中国 - Chuugoku) and 'all day long' (一日中 - ichinichijuu).
meaning_mm: အလယ်၊ အတွင်း

description: Means 'half'. It is commonly used when telling time, for example, 二時半 (niji han) means 'half past two' or 2:30.
Represents 'year'. It is used to count years (e.g., 2025年) and in words like 'last year' (去年 - kyonen) and 'this year' (今年 - kotoshi).
Means 'time' or 'hour'. Used as a counter for the hour (e.g., 一時 - ichiji, one o'clock). Also found in the word 'time' (時間 - jikan).
meaning_mm: အချိန်၊ နာရီ

description: A versatile kanji meaning 'minute' (fun/pun), 'to divide' (wakeru), or 'to understand' (wakaru). In the context of time, 一分 is 'ippun'.
onyomi: フン, ブン, プン
meaning_mm: မိနစ်၊ အပိုင်း၊ နားလည်သည်

description: The essential question word for 'what'. It is read as 'nan' before certain counters (e.g., 何時 - nanji, what time?) and 'nani' in other cases (e.g., 何ですか - nani desu ka, what is it?).
The standard, polite word for 'I' or 'me'. It can also mean 'private' in some contexts, like 私立 (shiritsu - private establishment).
meaning_mm: ကျွန်တော်/ကျွန်မ၊ ပုဂ္ဂလိက

description: Means 'father'. Read as 'chichi' when referring to your own father and お父さん (otousan) when addressing him or talking about someone else's father.
Means 'mother'. Read as 'haha' when referring to your own mother and お母さん (okaasan) when addressing her or talking about someone else's mother.
Means 'child'. It's often seen in words like 'child' (子供 - kodomo), 'boy' (男の子 - otoko no ko) and 'girl' (女の子 - onna no ko).
Means 'man' or 'male'. Found in words like 'man' (男の人 - otoko no hito) and 'boy' (男の子 - otoko no ko).
Means 'woman' or 'female'. Found in words like 'woman' (女の人 - onna no hito) and 'girl' (女の子 - onna no ko).
meaning_mm: မိန်းမ၊ အမ

description: Means 'mountain'. A very common kanji found in names and geographical terms. For example, Mt. Fuji is 富士山 (Fujisan).
Means 'river'. The reading can change to '-gawa' when it's the second part of a compound word, like in 中川 (Nakagawa), a common surname.
Means 'rice paddy' or 'rice field'. This is an extremely common kanji in Japanese surnames, such as 山田 (Yamada) and 田中 (Tanaka). The reading often changes to '-da'.
A versatile kanji meaning 'life', 'to live' (生きる - ikiru), or 'to be born' (生まれる - umareru). It's a key part of words like 'student' (学生 - gakusei) and 'teacher' (先生 - sensei).
kunyomi: い.きる, う.まれる, なま
meaning: life, to live, to be born, student
meaning_mm: ဘဝ၊ အသက်ရှင်သည်၊ မွေးဖွားသည်၊ ကျောင်းသား

description: Means 'ahead', 'previous', or 'before'. It combines with 生 to form 'teacher' (先生 - sensei, literally 'one born before'). Also used for 'last week' (先週 - senshuu).
meaning_mm: ရှေ့၊ အရင်၊ ဦးစွာ

description: Relates to 'learning', 'study', or 'school'. It combines with 生 to mean 'student' (学生 - gakusei) and with 校 for 'school' (学校 - gakkou).
meaning_mm: သင်ယူသည်၊ လေ့လာသည်၊ ကျောင်း

description: Means 'school' or 'exam'. It is most often seen combined with 学 to form the word for school (学校 - gakkou).
Means 'friend'. The most common word using this kanji is 友達 (tomodachi).
meaning_mm: သူငယ်ချင်း

description: Means 'book', 'origin', or 'main'. It is also used as a counter for long, cylindrical objects. It is the 'hon' in Nihon (日本 - Japan).
meaning_mm: စာအုပ်၊ မူလ၊ အဓိက

description: Means 'every'. It's used as a prefix in time-related words like 'every day' (毎日 - mainichi), 'every week' (毎週 - maishuu), and 'every year' (毎年 - maitoshi/mainen).
Means 'language' or 'word'. It's used as a suffix for languages, such as Japanese (日本語 - Nihongo) and English (英語 - Eigo).
meaning_mm: ဘာသာစကား၊ စကားလုံး

description: Relates to 'sentence', 'writing', or 'literature'. Used in words like 'grammar' (文法 - bunpou) and 'literature' (文学 - bungaku).
meaning_mm: ဝါကျ၊ စာပေ၊ အရေးအသား

description: A fundamental verb meaning 'to go' (行く - iku). It is also read as 'kou' in compound words like 'bank' (銀行 - ginkou) or 'gyou' for 'line' or 'row'.
A fundamental irregular verb meaning 'to come' (来る - kuru). The 'on' reading 'rai' is used in time words like 'next week' (来週 - raishuu) and 'next month' (来月 - raigetsu).
meaning_mm: လာသည်၊ နောက်

description: The verb 'to see', 'to look', or 'to watch' (見る - miru). It is also part of the verb 'to show' (見せる - miseru).
meaning_mm: ကြည့်သည်၊ မြင်သည်

description: Means 'to eat' (食べる - taberu). The 'on' reading 'shoku' is used in words like 'cafeteria' (食堂 - shokudou) and 'food' (食べ物 - tabemono).
meaning_mm: စားသည်၊ အစားအစာ

description: Means 'to drink' (飲む - nomu). It is used in compound words like 'beverage' (飲み物 - nomimono) and 'drinking and eating' (飲食 - inshoku).
Means 'to buy' (買う - kau). A common related word is 'shopping' (買い物 - kaimono).
A common adjective meaning 'high', 'tall', or 'expensive' (高い - takai). Also used in words like 'high school' (高校 - koukou).
meaning_mm: မြင့်သည်၊ အရပ်ရှည်သည်၊ ဈေးကြီးသည်

description: Means 'cheap' or 'inexpensive' (安い - yasui). It can also mean 'peaceful' or 'safe', as in the word 安全 (anzen - safety).
Means 'big' or 'large' (大きい - ookii). The 'on' reading 'dai' is used in words like 'university' (大学 - daigaku) and 'important' (大事 - daiji).
Means 'small' or 'little' (小さい - chiisai). The 'on' reading 'shou' is used in words like 'elementary school' (小学校 - shougakkou).
kunyomi: ちい.さい, こ, お

description: Means 'new' (新しい - atarashii). The 'on' reading 'shin' is used in words like 'newspaper' (新聞 - shinbun) and 'Shinkansen' (新幹線 - bullet train).
